title: Strade Bianche 2025 tech gallery: New tyres, gravel wheels and Zipp’s smart wheels
content:
Cyclist
Strade Bianche 2025 tech gallery: New tyres, gravel wheels and Zipp’s smart wheels

The Classics are always the place to see teams being inventive with setups and new technology. While things have become far less radical in recent years as the peloton has adopted wider tyres, there’s still plenty of interesting details to notice.

Strade Bianche is the perfect example of that, and this year’s edition saw largely normal looking bikes with a few nice touches if you look closer, including some unreleased products.

We sent photographer Xavier Pereyron into the thick of the action to see what he could find before he shot the men’s race.

Uno-X’s new Ridley Noah Fast aero bikes have drawn a lot of attention this year with their enormous head tubes, but that’s not the standout feature here…

… They were actually using gravel wheels from DT Swiss.

Intermarché-Wanty were also riding wheels worth talking about.

Their Newmen Streem wheels are new, said to be very lightweight and feature hidden valves, which you can just about make out here.

They were also using brand new Hutchinson Blackbird Race tyres, which you can read more about here.

Israel-Premier Tech’s Factor Ostro VAM’s were fitted with 55T aero FSA TT chainrings.

There’s a reason why they call Ben Turner ‘Big Ben’.

Polti-VisitMalta went with shallower rims than most, but like many they were riding 30mm Vittoria tyres – they were just a couple of days early for the Italian brand’s new 29mm wide-rim specific range.

Do bikes get prettier than this? Probably not. Jayco-AlUla had a mix of tyres on the go, most went with 32mm Vittorias…

… However there were some brand new Cadex aero tyres on show.

Italian team Solution Tech-Vini Fantini have plenty of tech not seen on the WorldTour level at the moment, with bikes from Chinese manufacturer Pardus and EliteWheels’ Drive wheels – read more about those here.

Cofidis have brought Campagnolo back to the WorldTour this season and don’t the Bora Ultra WTO wheels look great on those Looks.

When we recently reviewed the BMC Teammachine R 01, as ridden by Tudor Pro Cycling, tech editor Sam Challis noted its only drawback was the wheel and tyre combo. That shouldn’t have been an issue for Marc Hirschi, who, like Uno-X, had DT Swiss gravel wheels as well as wider tyres than the 26mm normally specced.

Fairly straightforward setup for Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe’s Jan Tratnik.

XDS-Astana’s new X-Lab bikes look even more aero with the full Italian tricolore.

Soudal-QuickStep had some Specialized ‘black label’ unreleased tyres on the go.

Arkéa-Samsic is the peloton’s Bianchi representative at the moment, and you’d surely prefer to be a rider with the full celeste paintjob. You can see here the team mechanics are filling these tyres with 40ml of sealant.

Groupama-FDJ have moved to Miche wheels for 2025, and paired them with Continental Aero 111 front tyre.

Decathlon-AG2R were using SwissSide’s Hadron² All-Road wheels with big (but not the aero) Continental tyres.

Despite Visma playing a role in the development of those new Vittoria 29mm tyres, Ben Tulett was on 30mms.

More Vision wheels and 30mm Vittoria tyres for EF.

Tom Pidcock’s teammate Milan Vader was on the super-lightweight Scott Addict RC.

He was also one of the riders using Zipp’s unreleased 303 wheels with an integrated tyre pressure sensor.

Yes that’s blood. Check out our gallery of the men’s race to see who it belongs to.

Cyclist Track Days 2025 bikes #1: Van Rysel RCR

Paris-Nice 2025 preview: Route, favourites, how to watch and start list

Onto the women’s peloton now, and the EF-Oatly team had similar choices to the men’s team, but didn’t have Noemi Rüegg’s excellent Swiss champion paintjob.

Italian team Top Girls Fassa Bortolo have a very interesting mix of tech, with their Pinarello Dogma Fs paired with a Shimano Ultegra groupset and Campagnolo Bora WTO wheels.

Mendelspeck E-Work use bikes from Italian brand Dynatek.

Their fellow Continental team Isolmant-Premac-Vittoria are on these Guerciotti bikes, and you can certainly tell they’re sponsored by Vittoria looking at those wheels.

Surprisingly they’re still running tubulars.

Kasia Niewiadoma was sporting a Canyon Aeroad with one of the brand’s new colour schemes.

As a SRAM-sponsored team it’s no surprise they’re also using Zipp’s new wheels, this time the light’s on.

Plenty of riders in the women’s peloton are running negative stem angles to keep their position aggressive and aero.

Yes 3T still has a place in pro racing courtesy of the Aromitalia 3T Vaiano team.

UAE Team ADQ’s bikes are more familiar in these parts, with the same tech as the men’s team.

It’s the same story with AG Insurance-Soudal and Soudal-QuickStep, with the women’s team running those unreleased Specialized tyres too.

Pauline Ferrand-Prévot had a good day out riding to third on this Cervélo S5 with 30mm Vittoria tyres.

The race winner’s bike. Demi Vollering brought Specialized with her to FDJ-Suez, but not the tyres, she was running GP5000s.

Turns out the decision was victory.

And there she is.

Human Powered Health got the tyre memo for their Factor Ostro VAM, and like Israel-Premier Tech they use Factor’s Black Inc wheels, with 48mm deep rims on the front and 58mm on the rear.

Unlike the men’s team, Uno-X’s women’s squad were using DT Swiss road wheels and Continental Aero 111 tyres.

More 30mm Vittorias for Liv-AlUla-Jayco.

Basque team Laboral Kutxa-Fundación Euskadi are riding Mendiz bikes with these Token OSPWs.

Hopefully Sandra Alonso changed shoes before the race began.

Anna van der Breggen had a pretty standard setup, though this bike is probably very different to the one she rode in her previous pro stint.

Her teammate Lorena Wiebes wasn’t a big feature in the race but it’s still worth checking in on her Euro champs bike.

Whether ‘the show must go on’ is a reference to Van der Breggen’s return or SD Worx’s down year is TBC.

With Lapierre parting ways with both FDJ teams the French brand now sponsor the Picnic-Post NL teams, who use Ursus wheels.

Movistar had the tyre pressure sensor too, they also were wearing some unreleased Fizik shoes.

Come back tomorrow for detailed pictures of Tadej Pogačar’s bike.

The post Strade Bianche 2025 tech gallery: New tyres, gravel wheels and Zipp’s smart wheels appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Will Strickson | Website Editor
